summary: Email correspondence between legal representatives regarding the posthumous handling of Jeffrey Epstein's estate and discovery materials from his criminal case. The emails discuss providing search warrant inventories from the New York property search to the estate trustees, note that Epstein's defense counsel returned/destroyed discovery materials after his suicide, and attempt to schedule a meeting to discuss potential government forfeiture claims.

persons.name: Marc
persons.context: Addressed in email regarding providing search warrant returns to the trustees and scheduling a meeting about government forfeiture claims.

persons.name: Andy
persons.role: Partner, Co-Chair of White Collar Defense at Hu hes Hubbard & Reed LLP
persons.context: Sender of the initial email requesting search warrant inventories and proposing meeting dates; extends New Year's greetings.

connections.description: Andy is communicating with Marc regarding legal matters related to the Epstein estate, specifically search warrant materials and meeting scheduling.

events.title: Initial request for search warrant inventories
events.description: Andy sends an email to Marc requesting search warrant returns/inventories from searches of Epstein's New York and New Mexico properties and proposes meeting dates in early January.

events.title: Clarification on discovery materials
events.description: A follow-up email clarifies that Epstein's defense counsel returned or destroyed discovery materials after Epstein's suicide, per the protective order, but search warrant inventories might be available separately.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein's suicide
events.description: Referenced as the point after which Epstein's defense counsel returned or destroyed discovery materials pursuant to a protective order.

events.title: Discovery letter sent to counsel
events.description: Mentioned as the date a discovery letter was sent to Epstein's counsel, noting that some pages of search warrant returns were marked Confidential under a protective order.

locations: New York property (referenced in search warrant returns)
New Mexico property (referenced as not searched)
island property (likely Little St. James, referenced in search warrant return review)
New York, NY 10004-1482 (law firm office location)
keyFacts: Epstein's criminal defense counsel returned or destroyed discovery materials after his suicide, pursuant to a protective order.
Search warrant inventories from the New York property search (specifically USAO_4381-4445 and USAO_2662-4380) were produced to defense counsel and may be available separately.
The government had not searched Epstein's New Mexico property at the time of this correspondence.
A meeting was being arranged between estate trustees and the Chief of the Criminal Division to discuss potential government forfeiture claims against Epstein's estate.
Some pages of the search warrant returns were marked as Confidential under a protective order as of July 31, 2019.
